info.game_comments:
1998 College Championship semifinal game 1.
  From Zellerbach Auditorium at the University of California-Berkeley.

(1, 1).clue: From the Latin for "brother" comes this term for some mendicant monks; Tuck was one

(2, 1).clue: On maps, this rodent's name precedes creek, falls, island, &, of course, dam

(4, 1).clue: These "lip-smacking" treats were introduced by Hershey's in 1907

(5, 1).clue: It's the breed of dog seen here(just 1, not 101)

(6, 1).clue: Her father is Fred; her mother, Wilma

(1, 2).clue: In Zoroastrianism, water & a liquid called haoma are sacrificed in the presence of this substance

(2, 2).clue: Belomancy is a form of divination in which these are drawn at random from a quiver or other container

(4, 2).clue: This original Herman Munster on TV wrote the children's book "A Chocolate Moose for Dinner"

(5, 2).clue: This breed might want to change its name to Beijingese

(6, 2).clue: Keith, Brian, Mick, Bill & Charlie on drums

(1, 3).clue: Between February 11 & July 16, 1858, the Virgin Mary made a reported 18 appearances at this site

(2, 3).clue: Some foreign X-ray scanners may ruin rolls of this, so keep them in a special lead-lined bag

(4, 3).clue: Chocolate for eating is divided into 3 tastes: sweet, semisweet & this, which has little sugar

(5, 3).clue: The dog seen here is the English, not the pit type, of this terrier

(1, 4).clue: The Theravada school considers itself the closest to the original form of this religion

(2, 4).clue: The Kennedy Center's grand foyer is lit with 18 of these crystal items; they each weigh a ton

(4, 4).clue: Introduced in 1896, these chewy chocolates were the first wrapped penny candy

(5, 4).clue: Everyone "nose" this is the breed of the mug seen here

(6, 4).clue: He's the principal anchor of "Dateline NBC"

(1, 5).clue: The Hindu trinity is Brahma, Vishnu & this god

(2, 5).clue: Dedicated in 1910, the capitol building in this Kentucky city was designed to resemble the U.S. capitol

(4, 5).clue: This British company makes about 300 million creme eggs a year, exporting about 1/3 of them

(5, 5).clue: This breed used to guard monasteries

(6, 5).clue: From 760 feet up on this crater, you get a great view of Honolulu

(1, 1).clue: In 1998 Washington National Airport was renamed in honor of this president on his 87th birthday

(2, 1).clue: The U.S. signed its first international treaty Feb. 6, 1778 with this country

(3, 1).clue: This man who's Jakob's father & is old enough to be your grandfather won for the album "Time Out of Mind"

(4, 1).clue: From the Hindi word jagannath, it's an advancing force crushing all in its path

(6, 1).clue: Geologists dig up & study these organic remains, whose name is from the Latin for "dug up"

(1, 2).clue: His assassination in 1865 came only 5 days after the surrender at Appomattox

(2, 2).clue: The first joint American-Russian spacewalk was April 29, 1997 outside this space station

(3, 2).clue: Singer heard here with her Record & Song of the Year("Sunny Came Home")

(4, 2).clue: French for "stroke of mercy", in reality it's a death blow

(5, 2).clue: Feel no pain as you spell...

(6, 2).clue: Slate is this type of rock, the result of alterations to existing rocks

(1, 3).clue: Between his 2 nonconsecutive terms as president, he practiced law in New York City

(2, 3).clue: On Dec. 28, 1832 Andrew Jackson said John C. ya later to this man, the first vice president to resign

(3, 3).clue: "I Believe" this R. Kelly hit was named Best R&B Song

(4, 3).clue: Literally "god from a machine", this term refers to a god introduced to resolve a plot

(5, 3).clue: Don't lose your way as you spell...

(6, 3).clue: A speleologist studies caves; this is another name for a caver who explores caves as a hobby

(1, 4).clue: Many Americans blamed the Great Depression on this man who was president when it began in 1929

(2, 4).clue: On Oct. 10, 1920 Bill Wambsganss caught a line drive & tagged 2 players for the first of these in a World Series

(3, 4).clue: Following Ellen DeGeneres & Paul Reiser in previous years, this sitcom star hosted the show

(4, 4).clue: French for "famous case", it's any celebrated controversy that attracts great public attention

(6, 4).clue: Until it's cooled, the object seen here was this substance

(1, 5).clue: Good looks & support of compromise got this New Hampshirite elected in 1852 at age 47

(2, 5).clue: This model seen here became the first commercially available modern car of its type, Dec. 5, 1996

(3, 5).clue: This band from Oxford got their diploma, a Grammy for the album "OK Computer"

(4, 5).clue: This noun from the Italian for "skilled" is often applied to top musicians

(5, 5).clue: It'll be peculiar if you can't spell...

(6, 5).clue: 2-word term for the branch of geology that studies the phenomenon of continental drift

(0, 0).clue: Phoenix lies on a river named for this substance found in the name of another state capital
